study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, efficacy, and tolerability of Ashwagandha root extract in improving general health and sleep quality in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in quality of life, sleep quality, and mental alertness in the Ashwagandha group compared to placebo, with good tolerability and no reported safety concerns.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 65-80 years of either gender.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and summarize the current state and implications of Ashwagandha in treating various brain disorders, focusing on its neuroactive phytoconstituents, pharmacological effects, and mechanistic pathways.
results_summary: The study identified multiple neuroprotective phytoconstituents in Ashwagandha with potential benefits for brain disorders such as anxiety, Alzheimer's, and Parkinson's, supported by preclinical studies and patents. However, clinical data on mechanistic pathways and efficacy remains scarce and inconclusive.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad focus on brain disorders in general).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the active phytoconstituents, pharmacologic activities, mechanisms of action, potential applications, and safety profile of Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera).
results_summary: The study found that Ashwagandha exhibits a broad range of biological effects, including anti-cancer, anti-inflammatory, anti-diabetic, and neuroprotective properties, with potential benefits in reducing oxidative stress and inflammation. It also highlighted the role of Withaferin-A as a key phytoconstituent.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of preclinical and clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stress-relieving effects of high-concentration Ashwagandha root extract in stressed healthy adults, focusing on dose-response relationships.
results_summary: Ashwagandha significantly reduced perceived stress (PSS scores) and serum cortisol levels at both 250 mg/day and 600 mg/day doses, with greater effects at the higher dose. Participants also experienced significant improvement in sleep quality compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Stressed healthy adults (60 participants, male and female) with baseline PSS scores >20.
effective_dosage: 125 mg or 300 mg twice daily (total 250 mg/day or 600 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of Ashwagandha root extract in improving sleep quality and reducing anxiety in patients with insomnia.
results_summary: Ashwagandha significantly improved sleep onset latency, sleep efficiency, sleep quality, and anxiety scores compared to placebo after 10 weeks of treatment. The study found no significant adverse effects, indicating good tolerability.
population_specificity: 60 patients with insomnia and anxiety, randomly divided into test (n=40) and placebo (n=20) groups.
effective_dosage: 300 mg of full-spectrum Ashwagandha root extract twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the health benefits, safety, and mechanisms of action of Ashwagandha (Withania Somnifera), particularly its potential anti-carcinogenic properties.
results_summary: The study found that Ashwagandha has demonstrated benefits against various illnesses, including epilepsy, depression, arthritis, and diabetes, and shows potential as an anti-carcinogenic agent. Clinical trials indicated safety, and Withaferin A (WFA) exhibited cytotoxic activity against several cancers, though the exact mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from epilepsy, depression, arthritis, diabetes, and various cancers (breast, colon, prostate, ovarian, lung, brain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ashwagandha tea, alone or combined with matcha tea, in protecting against oxidative injury and cell death in the uterus and ovaries of female rats.
results_summary: Ashwagandha tea, along with matcha, improved biochemical and microscopic markers of oxidative injury and cell death in uterine and ovarian tissues, though the best improvement was observed in the matcha-administered group.
population_specificity: Adult female rats with induced utero-ovarian oxidative injury.
effective_dosage: 100 mg kg⁻¹ b.wt. and 200 mg kg⁻¹ b.wt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anxiolytic effects of Ashwagandha on adults with self-reported high stress and examine potential mechanisms related to its therapeutic effects.
results_summary: Ashwagandha supplementation significantly reduced anxiety (HAM-A) and stress markers (cortisol, DHEA-S) compared to placebo, with near-significant reductions in DASS-21. Testosterone levels increased in males but not significantly compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Stressed, healthy adults (n=60).
effective_dosage: 240 mg of standardized Ashwagandha extract (Shoden) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-hypothyroidism potential of ashwagandha methanolic extract (AME) in a propylthiouracil-induced hypothyroidism animal model.
results_summary: AME significantly improved thyroid hormone levels (T3, T4), reduced oxidative stress markers, and enhanced thyroid gland histology, outperforming the standard anti-hypothyroidism drug in some measures. It also mitigated adverse metabolic and inflammatory changes induced by hypothyroidism.
population_specificity: Animal model (propylthiouracil-induced hypothyroidism)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Ashwagandha (WSE) as an adjunctive treatment for depression and anxiety symptoms in patients with schizophrenia experiencing an exacerbation of positive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found medium effect sizes favoring Ashwagandha over placebo for reducing depression and anxiety symptoms in schizophrenia patients. Adverse events were mild and transient.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia experiencing an exacerbation of positive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the stress resistance-promoting effects of triethylene glycol (TEG) and withanolide-free Ashwagandha root extract (WFWS) in mice.
results_summary: WFWS at doses up to 10 mg/kg/day was as effective as TEG in protecting against stress-induced changes in body weight, core temperature, and marble-burying behavior. Higher doses (33.3 and 100 mg/kg) also protected against stress-triggered alterations in blood glucose, insulin levels, and exhibited antidepressant or anxiolytic-like effects.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to foot shock stress and marble-burying tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adjunctive treatment with a standardized Ashwagandha extract (WSE) improves psychopathology and stress in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.
results_summary: WSE significantly reduced PANSS negative, general, and total symptoms, as well as perceived stress, compared to placebo. CRP and S100B levels declined more in the WSE group but were not statistically significant. Adverse events were mild to moderate and transient.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder experiencing symptom exacerbation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Withaferin A and Withanone from Ashwagandha could restore wild-type p53 function in cancer cells harboring specific p53 mutations.
results_summary: The study found that Withaferin A, Withanone, and an extract rich in these withanolides selectively restored wild-type p53 function in p53Y220C mutant cells, leading to growth arrest and apoptosis. No significant effects were observed for other p53 mutations (p53V143A, p53R249S, p53R273H).
population_specificity: Human cancer cell lines with specific p53 mutations (p53V143A, p53R249S, p53R273H, p53Y220C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of Ashwagandha root hot water extract (ASH-WEX) on skin using human keratinocyte cells and mouse skin.
results_summary: ASH-WEX significantly reduced inflammatory cytokine expression (IL-8, IL-6, TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-12) and increased anti-inflammatory TGF-β1 in HaCaT cells and mouse skin, likely by suppressing NF-κB and MAPK pathways.
population_specificity: Human keratinocyte cell line (HaCaT) and mouse skin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of daily ashwagandha extract supplementation compared to placebo in subjects with nonrestorative sleep (NRS) over six weeks, as measured by the Restorative Sleep Questionnaire-weekly version (RSQ-W).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design suggests it will assess ashwagandha's impact on NRS using objective (actigraphy, polysomnography) and subjective (RSQ-W, HADS, WHOQOL) measures, along with inflammatory markers like C-reactive protein.
population_specificity: Individuals with nonrestorative sleep (NRS) identified using the RSQ-W questionnaire.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and apoptotic effects of Ashwagandha leaf extract on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells.
results_summary: Ashwagandha water extract (ASH-WX) demonstrated increased cytotoxicity, enhanced antioxidant activities, elevated Fas-ligand levels, and increased caspase-3, -8, and -9 activities while reducing TNF-α levels in HepG2 cells. Molecular docking suggested strong binding to cyclin D1, and cell cycle analysis showed accumulation in G0/G1 and G2/M phases.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma cell line (HepG2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Ashwagandha in improving male fertility by examining its effects on semen quality, oxidative stress, and hormonal balance.
results_summary: Ashwagandha improved sperm count and motility, reduced lipid peroxidation, and regulated reproductive hormone levels, though its molecular mechanisms remain unclear. The study suggests both direct (oxidative stress mitigation) and indirect (hormonal balance via GABA-like pathways) mechanisms.
population_specificity: Infertile men (human and animal studies referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the effects of Kunapa jala (KJ) and Pancha gavya (PG) on the germination parameters of Ashwagandha and Kalamegha seeds compared to other treatments.
results_summary: KJ and PG showed good nutrient content and were effective in improving germination parameters, with KJ performing better than PG but both being outperformed by NPK.
population_specificity: Ashwagandha and Kalamegha seeds (plant-based study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ashwagandha root extract exhibits analgesic effects in rat models of postoperative and neuropathic pain.
results_summary: Ashwagandha root extract significantly increased mechanical withdrawal thresholds and reduced pain-related behaviors in rat models, while also alleviating hyperalgesia and cytokine levels in neuropathic pain. The active compound withaferin A showed CCR2 antagonistic effects, suggesting a potential mechanism for pain relief.
population_specificity: Rat models (plantar incision and spared nerve injury)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ashwagandha root extract in improving thyroid function in patients with subclinical hypothyroidism.
results_summary: Ashwagandha significantly improved serum TSH, T3, and T4 levels compared to placebo, with minimal and temporary adverse effects reported in a small fraction of participants.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-50 with elevated serum TSH levels (4.5-10 μIU/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Ashwagandha root could ameliorate nonclassic 11-hydroxylase deficiency, building on prior findings of its effects on similar enzyme deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that Ashwagandha root appeared to ameliorate nonclassic 11-hydroxylase deficiency, with effects that were dose-related. This is the first report of its use for this specific condition.
population_specificity: An elderly woman with acne and male pattern alopecia due to nonclassic 11-hydroxylase deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ashwagandha in improving memory and cognitive functioning in adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The ashwagandha treatment group showed significant improvements in immediate and general memory, executive function, sustained attention, and information-processing speed compared to the placebo group. These improvements were supported by multiple validated cognitive tests.
population_specificity: Adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active sleep-inducing components of Ashwagandha leaves and evaluate their effects on sleep regulation in mice.
results_summary: The alcoholic extract of Ashwagandha was ineffective, but the water extract containing triethylene glycol significantly increased non-rapid eye movement sleep in mice. Commercially available triethylene glycol also showed dose-dependent sleep-inducing effects.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ashwagandha leaf extract (i-Extract) has cholinergic properties that counteract scopolamine-induced cholinergic deficits in mice.
results_summary: The study found that i-Extract attenuated scopolamine-induced disruptions in the cholinergic system, evidenced by restored acetylcholine levels and Arc gene expression. Biochemical and molecular analyses supported its cholinergic activity.
population_specificity: Scopolamine-induced amnesic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioactive components (Withanolides, Withaferin-A, and Withanone) in Ashwagandha leaves versus roots and explore hydroponic cultivation methods to optimize their content.
results_summary: The study found that Ashwagandha leaves contain higher levels of active Withanolides (Withaferin-A and Withanone) than roots. Hydroponic cultivation under manipulated light conditions yielded leaves with a high Withanone/Withaferin-A ratio, and cyclodextrin-based extracts were prepared to achieve desired ratios, suggesting potential value for cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a standardized Ashwagandha root extract for reducing stress and aiding body weight management in adults under chronic stress.
results_summary: Ashwagandha significantly improved primary (stress and food cravings) and secondary (happiness, eating behavior, cortisol levels, body weight, and BMI) measures. The extract was found to be safe and tolerable.
population_specificity: 52 adults under chronic stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of Withania somnifera (Ashwagandha) root extract as an adjunct therapy to SSRIs in treating OCD.
results_summary: The study found that Ashwagandha significantly reduced OCD symptom severity compared to placebo, as measured by the Y-BOCS scale, with no reported adverse events. The extract was deemed safe and effective as an adjunct to SSRIs.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with a confirmed DSM-IV-TR diagnosis of OCD, all under SSRI treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether ashwagandha could mitigate inflammation induced by TNF-α and LPS in vitro, specifically focusing on its potential to attenuate chemokine expression (CCL2 and CCL5) and NF-κB activation.
results_summary: Ashwagandha water-soluble extract (WSE) completely prevented TNF-α-induced increases in CCL5, attenuated CCL2 expression and NF-κB activation, and showed similar protective effects against LPS-induced inflammation.
population_specificity: In vitro study (cell-based model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Brahmyadi Churna and tablet Shilajatu (with milk as Anupana) in managing essential hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that 19 out of 40 patients showed marked improvement, 14 had moderate improvement, and 5 had mild improvement, with a significant reduction in blood pressure (P < 0.000). No improvement was observed in 2 individuals.
population_specificity: 40 patients with essential hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of high-concentration ashwagandha root extract (HCARE) for improving sexual function in healthy women.
results_summary: HCARE significantly improved sexual function scores (FSFI and FSDS) and increased successful sexual encounters compared to placebo. The improvements were statistically significant across multiple domains, including arousal, lubrication, orgasm, and satisfaction.
population_specificity: Healthy females

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory effects of the herbomineral formulation TEBEH (containing Ashwagandha) on LPS-induced cytokine expression in mouse splenocytes.
results_summary: TEBEH significantly inhibited pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, MIP-1α) while upregulating IFN-γ, suggesting it promotes an anti-inflammatory environment, potentially via the NF-κB pathway. The formulation was safe up to 10.53 μg/mL and showed dose-dependent immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: Mouse splenocytes (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the apoptotic activity of methanol extract of Ashwagandha (MEAG) in human head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) cells and investigate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: MEAG showed dose-dependent growth-inhibitory activity via caspase-dependent apoptosis, involving mitochondrial membrane potential loss, cytochrome c release, and Bim protein upregulation. Withaferin A (WA), a bioactive component of MEAG, induced similar apoptotic effects.
population_specificity: Human head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-arthritic effects of aqueous extract of Ashwagandha root (WSAq) in collagen-induced arthritic rats.
results_summary: WSAq demonstrated dose-dependent reductions in arthritic index, autoantibodies, and inflammatory markers, with the highest efficacy at 300 mg/kg. It also ameliorated oxidative stress by improving antioxidant parameters, showing comparable effects to methotrexate.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritic (CIA) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Ayurvedic treatment (Ashwagandha powder and Sidh Makardhwaj) in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The treatment showed significant improvements in tender/swollen joint counts, pain assessment, and ESR levels, with 56.4% achieving ACR20 response. However, increased urinary mercury levels were observed post-treatment.
population_specificity: 86 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (78 completed the study) at an Ayurvedic hospital in New Delhi, India.
effective_dosage: 5g Ashwagandha powder twice daily for 3 weeks, followed by 100mg Sidh Makardhwaj daily for 4 weeks.
study_duration: 7 weeks total (3 weeks Ashwagandha, 4 weeks Sidh Makardhwaj).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ashwagandha's i-Extract could counteract scopolamine-induced amnesia by enhancing Arc protein function and F-actin polymerization in hippocampal neurons.
results_summary: The study found that Ashwagandha's i-Extract restored and enhanced F-actin polymerization and dendritic spine morphology disrupted by scopolamine or Arc antisense ODN, particularly in the CA1 hippocampal region, suggesting a role in memory recovery.
population_specificity: Scopolamine-induced amnesic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Withania somnifera (ashwagandha) in treating anxiety through a systematic review of human randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Five studies met inclusion criteria, with most showing significant improvements in anxiety or stress scores compared to placebo. However, all studies had unclear or high risk of bias, and methodological heterogeneity prevented meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Human subjects in randomized controlled trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified (multiple dosage levels were compared in some studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Ashwagandha extracts and active principles on brain pathologies, focusing on its neurodifferentiation, neuroregenerative, and neuroprotective potentials.
results_summary: The study highlights Ashwagandha's multidimensional effects, including differentiation of neuroblastoma and glioma cells, reversal of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's pathologies, protection against environmental neurotoxins, and memory enhancement. However, the active principles and mechanisms of action remain largely undefined.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer, antimigratory, anti-invasive, and anti-angiogenic effects of a combination of withanone and withaferin A derived from Ashwagandha.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of withanone and withaferin A selectively killed cancer cells and exhibited significant antimigratory, anti-invasive, and anti-angiogenic effects in both in vitro and in vivo assays. Bioinformatics and biochemical analyses indicated these effects were mediated through downregulation of migration-promoting proteins.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo assays, no human subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Ashwagandha supercritical CO2 extract derived Withanolides (ADW) could mitigate BPA-induced mitochondrial toxicity in HepG2 cells.
results_summary: ADW at 100 μg/ml protected HepG2 cells from BPA-induced toxicity by suppressing mitochondrial damage, increasing ATP production, and reducing oxidative stress markers like malondialdehyde while boosting antioxidant enzyme activities.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human liver cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the spermatogenic activity of Ashwagandha root extract in oligospermic patients.
results_summary: Ashwagandha treatment significantly increased sperm count (167%), semen volume (53%), and sperm motility (57%) compared to placebo, with minimal improvements in the placebo group. Serum hormone levels also showed greater regulation with Ashwagandha.
population_specificity: 46 male patients with oligospermia (sperm count < 20 million/mL semen).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neuroprotective effects of Ashwagandha extract against β-amyloid-induced toxicity and HIV-1Ba-L infection in human neuronal cells.
results_summary: Ashwagandha extract neutralized β-amyloid-induced cytotoxicity and HIV-1Ba-L infection effects in SK-N-MC cells, improving cell viability and PPARγ levels, indicating neuroprotective potential.
population_specificity: Human neuronal SK-N-MC cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer activity of Ashwagandha leaf water extract (ASH-WEX) and identify its active components.
results_summary: ASH-WEX showed selective cytotoxicity to cancer cells, suppressed tumors in vivo, and its active component, triethylene glycol (TEG), activated tumor suppressor proteins p53 and pRB while downregulating metastasis-related proteins MMP-3 and MMP-9 in cancer cells, with no adverse effects on normal cells.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Ashwagandha's alcoholic leaf extract (i-Extract) could recover scopolamine-induced amnesia in mice by modulating Arc protein expression in the hippocampus and cerebral cortex.
results_summary: The study found that i-Extract improved spatial learning and memory in scopolamine-treated mice, with molecular analysis showing recovery of Arc protein expression, particularly in the hippocampus. Pre-treatment with i-Extract was more effective than post-treatment.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Ashwagandha Churna supplementation combined with topical oil pooling (TOPMAC) in tinnitus suppression and hearing and cognitive function protection in elderly patients with mild to moderate presbycusis.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with data analysis yet to start; results are expected by January 2025. No findings regarding Ashwagandha's effects are currently available.
population_specificity: Patients aged 60-75 years with mild to moderate presbycusis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Withania somnifera (Ashwagandha) supplementation on cortisol levels in stressed humans by analyzing clinical trials.
results_summary: Ashwagandha supplementation decreased cortisol secretion with no significant adverse effects, but long-term effects and adrenal function impact were not evaluated.
population_specificity: Stressed individuals with varying degrees of stress.
effective_dosage: Varied across studies (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether liposomal ashwagandha supplementation improves cognitive function, mood, and health markers in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Ashwagandha supplementation improved measures of memory, attention, vigilance, and executive function while reducing tension and fatigue, with several significant differences observed between the ashwagandha and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Healthy young men and women (average age 22.7 ± 7 years, BMI 26.2 ± 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ashwagandha on stress, fatigue, and sex hormones in overweight or mildly obese adults with self-reported stress and fatigue.
results_summary: Ashwagandha supplementation was associated with a significant reduction in stress levels, but the improvements were not significantly different from the placebo group. Secondary outcomes suggested potential anti-fatigue effects, possibly mediated by the autonomic nervous system.
population_specificity: Overweight or mildly obese men and women aged 40-75 years with self-reported stress and fatigue.
effective_dosage: 200 mg of ashwagandha root extract (Witholytin®) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a proprietary blend of Ashwagandha (WS root) and Okra (AE fruit) in relieving constipation and improving quality of life in adults.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly reduced constipation symptoms, improved gastrointestinal function, sleep quality, and stress levels, while increasing beneficial biomarkers like serotonin and gastrin and decreasing cortisol and interleukin-6. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-60 with functional constipation (Rome-III criteria).
effective_dosage: 300 mg or 500 mg of CL18100F4 (proprietary blend).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Ashwagandha supplementation on anxiety and stress through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Ashwagandha supplementation significantly reduced anxiety (SMD: -1.55, 95% CI: -2.37, -0.74; p = .005), indicating a strong effect. The study included 12 eligible papers with a total sample size of 1,002 participants.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-48 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical evidence for Ashwagandha's role in managing cognitive dysfunction.
results_summary: Ashwagandha improved cognitive performance, executive function, attention, and reaction time in most cases, with good tolerability and minimal side effects. The evidence comes from randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trials, though the study populations were heterogeneous.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment and adults with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder, or bipolar disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and tolerability of Ashwagandha root extract in alleviating climacteric symptoms, improving quality of life, and modulating hormonal parameters in perimenopausal women.
results_summary: Ashwagandha significantly reduced climacteric symptoms (measured by MRS and MENQoL scores) and improved hormonal profiles (increased estradiol, decreased FSH and LH) compared to placebo, with no significant effect on testosterone levels.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women with climacteric symptoms (n=100, 91 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supramolecular assembly of salmon calcitonin with aspartame (sCT-APM) could improve bioavailability, therapeutic efficacy, and osteogenesis for osteoporosis therapy.
results_summary: The study found that sCT-APM nanoassemblies delayed fibrillation time, achieved sustained sCT release, showed good biocompatibility, and enhanced osteoinductive capacity compared to free sCT. In vivo results demonstrated a 2.42-fold increase in relative bioavailability and a 3.55-fold increase in therapeutic efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo study, likely animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame and acesulfame K in artificially sweetened beverages adversely affected glucose control in healthy, normal-weight, overweight, and obese subjects without Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found no harmful effect of the artificially sweetened soft drink on glucose control, with no significant differences in fasting glucose, insulin levels, or glucose tolerance compared to mineral water consumption. Continuous glucose monitoring also showed no significant changes after 2 weeks of intake.
population_specificity: 39 healthy subjects (BMI 18-45, age 18-75) without Type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 0.6 L/day of an artificially sweetened soft drink containing acesulfame K (950) and aspartame (951).
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention (crossover design with a 4-week washout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antihyperglycemic potential and hepatic safety of miracle fruit (MF) extracts versus aspartame in alloxan-induced diabetic mice.
results_summary: Aspartame significantly elevated alanine aminotransferase levels and caused destructive liver histopathology, while MF extracts restored hepatic architecture and improved hyperglycemia.
population_specificity: Alloxan-induced diabetic mice
effective_dosage: Not specified for aspartame (MF doses: 250 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg BW)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of long-term aspartame consumption on the reproductive system in male mice.
results_summary: The study found that aspartame consumption led to reproductive damage in male mice, including altered sperm parameters, reduced testosterone levels, increased oxidative stress, and decreased Hsp70-2 expression, particularly at higher doses (80 and 160 mg/kg).
population_specificity: Adult male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to differentiate between tumors and immune cell infiltrates in Sprague-Dawley rats exposed to Aspartame and assess its potential leukaemogenic and lymphomatogenic effects.
results_summary: The study confirmed a statistically significant increase in total hematolymphoid tumors (HLTs), lymphomas, and leukaemias in female rats exposed to high-dose Aspartame, reinforcing its potential carcinogenic effects. The re-evaluation supported previous findings of Aspartame's leukaemogenic and lymphomatogenic impact.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (female)
effective_dosage: High dose (specific amount not stated in abstract)
study_duration: Long-term (specific duration not stated in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the biochemical, histopathological, and genotoxic effects of aspartame (ASP) alone or combined with l-carnitine (LC) on rat liver.
results_summary: ASP increased liver enzyme activity, disrupted lipid profiles, reduced antioxidant markers, and elevated oxidative stress and DNA damage in a dose-dependent manner. LC co-treatment mitigated these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: ASP-LD (75 mg/kg), ASP-HD (150 mg/kg), LC (10 mg/kg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if aspartame supplementation in starter diets accelerates small intestinal cell cycle by stimulating GLP-2 secretion and expression in pre-weaned lambs.
results_summary: Aspartame supplementation increased GLP-2 concentration, jejunum weight/body weight, and crypt depth, while upregulating cell cycle-related genes in the small intestine. GLP-2 indirectly promoted jejunal cell proliferation via the IGF-1 pathway.
population_specificity: Pre-weaned lambs (14-day-old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the carcinogenic potential of aspartame, particularly in response to conflicting findings from the Ramazzini Institute.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of aspartame-induced tumors in any organ system, contradicting the Ramazzini Institute's findings. The only observed effects were renal pelvic mineralization and hyperplasia, deemed toxicologically insignificant.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a topical formulation containing CBD and aspartame (JW-100) could effectively relieve signs and symptoms of atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: JW-100 demonstrated statistically significant improvements in AD symptoms, with a greater reduction in ISGA scores compared to CBD alone or placebo. 50% of JW-100 patients achieved clear or almost clear skin, versus 20% and 15% in the CBD-only and placebo groups, respectively.
population_specificity: Patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of daily aspartame ingestion for 12 weeks on glycemia, with secondary aims of evaluating its impact on appetite and body weight.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of aspartame ingestion on glycemia, appetite, or body weight in healthy, lean adults, with no differences observed between the control and aspartame groups at baseline or week 12. Compliance with the intervention was high (~95%), and no adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Lean adults aged 18-60 years with a BMI of 18-25 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 0 mg/d (control), 350 mg/d, or 1050 mg/d of aspartame.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aspartame, with or without early nutritional deficiency, on anxiety-like behavior and cortical spreading depression (CSD) in developing rats.
results_summary: Aspartame dose-dependently reduced body weight, induced anxiety-like behavior (shorter stay in open arms in EPM), and decelerated CSD propagation speed, with stronger effects in nutritionally deficient conditions.
population_specificity: Newborn Wistar rats under favorable (L9) or unfavorable (L15) lactation conditions.
effective_dosage: 75 mg/kg/d or 125 mg/kg/d administered via gavage.
interactions: Interaction with lactation conditions (nutritional deficiency) noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of chronic aspartame exposure, starting in utero, on hypothalamic and adrenal gene expression, and how developmental NMDAR antagonism modulates these effects.
results_summary: Aspartame exposure increased the expression of genes related to hypothalamic neurosteroidogenesis, cell stress, and inflammation, as well as adrenal GABA and glutamate receptor subunits. These effects were absent in mice with developmental NMDAR antagonism.
population_specificity: Adult male mice exposed to aspartame developmentally (starting in utero).
interactions: Developmental NMDAR antagonism (CGP 39551) modulated aspartame's effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate structural and ultrastructural changes in the rat's brain cerebral cortex caused by aspartame and evaluate the potential protective effects of N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC) and folic acid (FA).
results_summary: Aspartame treatment caused severe degenerative changes in nerve cells, including shrinkage, irregular shapes, and swelling, along with weak Bcl-2 immunoexpression and intense GFAP immunoreactivity. NAC and FA combined showed a protective effect against aspartame-induced damage.
population_specificity: Adult rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether omega-3 fatty acids could mitigate aspartame-induced biochemical and morphological alterations in renal cells.
results_summary: Aspartame treatment reduced cell viability, caused DNA damage, and altered cell morphology, but these effects were reduced or reversed when omega-3 fatty acids were co-administered. Caspase-3 expression, a marker of apoptosis, increased with aspartame but decreased with omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: In vitro renal cells (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of early life stress and aspartame intake on metabolic and behavioral outcomes in rats.
results_summary: The study found that early maternal separation combined with aspartame intake led to increased blood glucose and hyperactivity in male rats but not in females, suggesting a potential risk for chronic diseases like diabetes.
population_specificity: Male and female rats subjected to maternal separation during breastfeeding.
study_duration: From postnatal day 26 to postnatal day 50 (24 days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aspartame on the medial Prefrontal Cortex (mPFC) and assess whether vitamin E could provide neuroprotective benefits against aspartame-induced damage.
results_summary: Aspartame consumption impaired long- and short-term memory and reduced mPFC volume, neuron count, and other structural metrics in rats. Vitamin E partially mitigated some of these effects, particularly at lower aspartame doses, but did not protect against all neurological impairments.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: Low dose (40mg/kg/day), high dose (200mg/kg/day), and vitamin E (100mg/kg/day)
interactions: Vitamin E (partial neuroprotective effect when co-administered with aspartame)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate evidence on whether aspartame consumption exacerbates mechanisms associated with Type II Diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: Aspartame may increase cortisol levels, induce oxidative stress, alter gut microbiota, and interfere with NMDA receptors, potentially leading to insulin deficiency or resistance. However, its safety for T2D remains debatable due to inconsistent data.
population_specificity: Individuals with Type II Diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silymarin co-administration could mitigate aspartame-induced behavioral, cognitive, and cerebral changes in mice.
results_summary: Silymarin co-administration with aspartame reduced adverse behavioral effects (e.g., locomotion, anxiety) and improved memory, while preserving cerebral cortical integrity and modulating antioxidant activity compared to aspartame alone.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: Aspartame at 160 or 320mg/kg daily; silymarin at 25mg/kg daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aspartame at various concentrations on cell viability, morphology, ROS levels, and DNA damage in human cervical carcinoma cells.
results_summary: Higher concentrations of aspartame significantly altered cell viability, increased mitochondria-derived ROS, induced DNA fragmentation, and led to apoptotic and necrotic cell formation in cervical carcinoma cells.
population_specificity: Human cervical carcinoma cells (HeLa cells)
study_duration: Two time periods of exposure (specific durations not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the degradation and mineralization of aspartame in aqueous solution using electrochemical advanced oxidation processes (EAOPs).
results_summary: The study found that almost complete mineralization of aspartame was achieved using a boron-doped diamond anode at 200 mA constant current electrolysis, with the absolute rate constant for the reaction between aspartame and hydroxyl radicals determined as (5.23 ± 0.02) × 10^9 M-1 s-1. The formation of carboxylic acids and inorganic ions was monitored, and the global toxicity of the treated solution was assessed using the Microtox® method.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether aspartame acts as a chemical stressor by evaluating changes in molecular mediators in rats.
results_summary: Aspartame administration led to increased corticosterone, lipid peroxidation, and nitric oxide levels, reduced antioxidant activity, and altered cytokine levels, suggesting immune function alteration. Methanol or formaldehyde metabolites may contribute to these changes.
population_specificity: Wistar Albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physiological effects of artificial sweeteners, particularly aspartame, on lipoprotein metabolism and their potential impact on antioxidant and anti-atherogenic functions of HDL.
results_summary: Aspartame-treated HDL showed loss of antioxidant ability, elevated atherogenic effects, and proteolytic degradation. Modified HDL exacerbated inflammatory death in zebrafish embryos, suggesting toxicity to the human circulatory system and embryonic development.
population_specificity: Human high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and zebrafish embryos.
effective_dosage: Final concentrations of 25, 50, and 100 mM aspartame.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of chronic low-dose aspartame consumption on obesity, metabolic parameters, and gut microbiota in a diet-induced obese rat model.
results_summary: Aspartame reduced calorie intake and weight gain but impaired glucose disposal and insulin tolerance. It also altered gut microbiota composition, increasing certain bacteria and affecting metabolic pathways linked to glucose regulation.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats on standard chow or high-fat diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic effects of a fructose-containing VLCD without aspartame versus traditional aspartame-containing VLCDs in obese subjects preparing for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the fructose-containing VLCD led to significant weight reduction and improved glucose and lipid control without adverse metabolic effects, but did not directly assess aspartame's role or safety.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (mean BMI 39.8 kg/m², mean age 48.8 years) preparing for bariatric surgery, including seven with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aspartame consumption and insulin treatment on CYP2E1 and CYP3A2 isozymes in the brain and liver of juvenile diabetic rats.
results_summary: Combined insulin and aspartame treatment significantly induced CYP2E1 in the cerebrum and cerebellum and increased CYP3A2 activity in both brain and liver, suggesting potential toxicological effects and altered drug metabolism.
population_specificity: Juvenile diabetic Wistar male rats (21-day-old postweaned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chronic effects of aspartame on ionic homeostasis and regional monoamine neurotransmitter concentrations in the brain.
results_summary: High-dose aspartame disrupted ionic homeostasis, induced brain apoptosis, and significantly decreased dopamine and serotonin levels in specific brain regions. It also altered tyrosine hydroxylase activity and amino acid levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal models, given the brain tissue analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether N-acetylcysteine could mitigate oxidative stress in rat brains caused by chronic aspartame consumption at the acceptable daily dose.
results_summary: Aspartame administration increased oxidative stress biomarkers in rat brains, while N-acetylcysteine treatment reduced these markers but did not fully restore all affected enzymes or glucose levels.
population_specificity: Rodents (rats)
effective_dosage: Aspartame (40 mg/kg, administered by gavage); N-acetylcysteine (150 mg/kg, intraperitoneal)
study_duration: Chronic administration (exact duration not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a rapid, simple, and stable biosensor for detecting aspartame in various sample matrices without pre-treatment.
results_summary: The biosensor demonstrated fast response times, high sample throughput (40 h⁻¹), and low detection limits (0.2 µM for aspartame). It was successfully applied to measure aspartame in commercial products without pre-treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on sample matrices/commercial products).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame could relieve atopic dermatitis (AD)-like symptoms induced by DNFB in NC/Nga mice.
results_summary: Aspartame at doses of 0.5 μg kg(-1) and 0.5 mg kg(-1) inhibited ear swelling, reduced inflammatory cell infiltration, suppressed cytokine expression (IL-4 and IFN-γ), and lowered total serum IgE levels, demonstrating therapeutic potential for AD. Sucrose had no effect.
population_specificity: NC/Nga mice with DNFB-induced AD-like symptoms.
effective_dosage: 0.5 μg kg(-1) and 0.5 mg kg(-1) (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genotoxic potential of aspartame and its metabolic breakdown products in mice using chromosomal aberration and sister chromatid exchange tests.
results_summary: Aspartame induced dose-dependent chromosomal aberrations but did not cause sister chromatid exchanges or decrease the mitotic index. Statistical analysis indicated that aspartame was not significantly genotoxic at low concentrations.
population_specificity: Swiss Albino male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of repeated aspartame administration on working memory, oxidative stress, and brain monoamines in mice.
results_summary: Aspartame at the highest dose (5.625 mg/kg) impaired water maze performance, increased oxidative stress markers (MDA, nitric oxide), and decreased GSH and glucose levels. It also caused dose-dependent inhibition of brain serotonin, noradrenaline, and dopamine.
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: 0.625, 1.875, or 5.625 mg/kg administered subcutaneously once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the angiogenic effects of Aspartame (APM) and its impact on inflammatory mediators and blood vessel formation in vitro.
results_summary: APM exposure induced blood vessel formation, increased ROS production in endothelial cells, and elevated levels of IL-6, VEGF-A, and their soluble receptors. APM also activated the VEGF pathway via erk1/2 and p38 phosphorylation, suggesting it acts as an angiogenic agent at low doses.
population_specificity: In vitro model using endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and the Angio-Kit system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the carcinogenic risk of aspartame when exposure begins during fetal life.
results_summary: The study found a significant dose-related increase in malignant tumors, lymphomas/leukemias, and mammary cancer in rats exposed to aspartame, particularly at higher doses (2,000 ppm). The results reinforced aspartame's multipotential carcinogenicity, especially when exposure starts prenatally.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (male and female) exposed from the 12th day of fetal life until natural death.
effective_dosage: 2,000 ppm, 400 ppm, or 0 ppm administered with feed.
study_duration: From the 12th day of fetal life until natural death.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic aspartame consumption affects cytochrome P450 enzyme activity in rat brain and liver.
results_summary: The study found that aspartame increased cytochrome P450 enzyme activity in rat brain (cerebrum and cerebellum) but not in the liver, with varying fold changes across different enzymes. The effects were dose-dependent, with the 75 mg/kg dose showing consistent increases.
population_specificity: Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term carcinogenic potential of Aspartame in rats under controlled experimental conditions.
results_summary: The study found that Aspartame increased the incidence of malignant tumors, lymphomas-leukemias, transitional cell carcinomas, and malignant schwannomas in rats, with dose-dependent trends and statistical significance. The results suggest Aspartame is a multipotential carcinogenic agent under the tested conditions.
population_specificity: Male and female Sprague-Dawley rats (100-150/sex/group), 8 weeks old at the start of the experiment.
study_duration: Treatment lasted until spontaneous death of the animals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame has carcinogenic effects in rats under long-term exposure.
results_summary: The study found that aspartame increased the incidence of malignant tumors, lymphomas, leukemias, transitional cell carcinomas, and malignant schwannomas in rats, with dose-dependent trends and statistical significance. The results suggest aspartame is a multipotential carcinogenic agent even at doses below the current acceptable daily intake.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (100-150/sex/group), 8 weeks old at study start.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genotoxic effects of aspartame using various tests, including chromosome aberration, sister chromatid exchange, micronucleus, and Ames/Salmonella/microsome tests.
results_summary: Aspartame induced chromosome aberrations dose-dependently at all concentrations and treatment periods, decreased mitotic index dose-dependently, and induced micronuclei at the highest concentrations. It did not induce sister chromatid exchanges or show mutagenic effects in Salmonella typhimurium strains.
population_specificity: Human lymphocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimutagenic effects of aspartame in combination with beta-carotene on reducing chromosome aberrations in mice exposed to clastogenic agents.
results_summary: The combination of aspartame and beta-carotene reduced clastogenic effects of dioxidine and cyclophosphamide in mice, showing a more potent and universal antimutagenic effect than either constituent alone. Both single and 5-day treatments demonstrated efficacy.
population_specificity: C57Bl/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic aspartame exposure has analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects similar to aspirin in a carrageenan-induced monoarthritis model.
results_summary: Aspartame at 50 mg/kg attenuated mechanical allodynia but did not reduce inflammation, increase motor activity, or affect thermal allodynia. Aspirin reduced mechanical hyperalgesia and inflammation but did not reverse thermal hyperalgesia or restore motor activity to control levels.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with carrageenan-induced monoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 100 mg/kg aspartame for six days; 150 mg/kg aspirin on the sixth day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Aspartame could prevent the accumulation of Ochratoxin A (OTA) in the brain and mitigate its neurotoxic effects in rats.
results_summary: Aspartame significantly reduced OTA accumulation in the brain and prevented OTA-induced changes in tyrosine and phenylalanine levels. It also reduced histological signs of neurotoxicity, such as necrotic cells with pyknotic nuclei.
population_specificity: Young adult rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the thermal stability of solid-state aspartame hemihydrate and identify impurity formation during heating.
results_summary: The study found that solid-state aspartame undergoes water evaporation, dehydration, and cyclization at specific temperatures (50, 110, and 153°C), leading to the formation of the impurity 3-carboxymethyl-6-benzyl-2,5-diketopiperazine (DKP). The novel FT-IR/DSC microscopic system effectively detected these thermal-dependent changes in a single step.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on solid-state aspartame)

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether aspartame disrupts cognitive, neurophysiologic, or behavioral functioning in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in neuropsychologic, neurophysiologic, or behavioral functioning between aspartame and placebo groups, even at high doses. Plasma phenylalanine levels increased during aspartame treatment, but no adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: 48 healthy young adults.
effective_dosage: High-dose (45 mg/kg body weight/day) and low-dose (15 mg/kg body weight/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic fate of aspartame in rats, focusing on the formation and binding of formaldehyde adducts to tissue components.
results_summary: The study found that aspartame-derived radioactivity was predominantly bound to proteins and nucleic acids, with significant retention in tissues, particularly the liver. Chronic aspartame administration led to cumulative formaldehyde adduct formation, suggesting potential long-term hazards.
population_specificity: Adult male rats, including a subset with cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if aspartame exhibits biological activity, including pain relief, antithrombotic effects, and antipyretic properties.
results_summary: Aspartame demonstrated pain relief in osteoarthritis patients, mild antithrombotic effects in humans, and reduced fever in rats. Results were statistically significant (p < 0.001 for pain relief, p < 0.01 for other effects).
population_specificity: Human subjects (osteoarthritis patients, normal volunteers) and Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding aspartame to a weight-control program improves weight loss and long-term weight maintenance in obese women.
results_summary: The study found that aspartame intake was positively correlated with greater weight loss during active weight loss and significantly less weight regain during maintenance and follow-up compared to the no-aspartame group. Exercise and self-reported eating control also positively influenced weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: 163 obese women
study_duration: 19-week weight-reduction program (16 weeks active weight loss), 1-year maintenance, and 2-year follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aspartame on cognitive function, EEGs, and biochemical parameters in heterozygotes for phenylketonuria (PKUH).
results_summary: The study found that aspartame had no effect on cognitive function, EEGs, or urinary organic acids. Plasma phenylalanine increased within the normal range for PKUH at the higher dose but did not result in adverse effects.
population_specificity: 48 adult heterozygotes for phenylketonuria (PKUH) (21 men, 27 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame ingestion is associated with headaches in individuals who self-reported headaches after aspartame use.
results_summary: The study found that subjects reported headaches on 33% of days during aspartame treatment compared to 24% on placebo (p = 0.04), with a subset of individuals ("very sure" of aspartame-triggered headaches) showing larger treatment differences. No significant differences were observed in headache length, intensity, or associated side effects.
population_specificity: Volunteers with self-identified headaches after aspartame use (n=32, with 18 completing the full protocol).
study_duration: Each experimental period was 7 days long.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of phenylalanine and aspartame on food intake in human volunteers, particularly focusing on potential appetite suppression.
results_summary: The study initially reported no effects on food intake from high doses of phenylalanine and aspartame, but a reanalysis of the raw data suggested dose-related suppression of food intake by phenylalanine and possible anorexic effects of aspartame and alanine. These findings indicate that amino acids and small peptides may influence appetite and warrant further investigation.
population_specificity: Human volunteers
effective_dosage: Up to 10.08 g of phenylalanine and aspartame in capsules

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame provokes seizures in children with well-documented seizure disorders.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between aspartame and placebo in EEG results, behavioral ratings, or biochemical measures, except for expected increases in phenylalanine and tyrosine after aspartame. Aspartame did not provoke seizures in this vulnerable group.
population_specificity: 10 children (5 boys, 5 girls, ages 5-13 years) with well-documented seizures (generalized convulsions, absence episodes, or complex partial seizures).

study_goal: To determine the effects of large doses of aspartame on behavior, cognition, and monoamine metabolism in children with attention deficit disorder.
results_summary: The study found no clinically significant differences between aspartame and placebo in behavioral, cognitive, or biochemical measures, except for expected increases in plasma phenylalanine and tyrosine. Aspartame at more than 10 times usual consumption had no effect on cognitive and behavioral status or monoamine excretion rates.
population_specificity: Children with attention deficit disorder (unmedicated, meeting DSM-3 criteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the appetite reduction observed after consuming aspartame-sweetened drinks was due to the drink volume or the aspartame content.
results_summary: The study found that appetite reduction was due to drink volume, not aspartame content. Consuming aspartame-sweetened carbonated mineral water increased subjective appetite, while encapsulated aspartame had no effect.
population_specificity: Eighteen normal-weight young adult males.
effective_dosage: 170 mg and 340 mg aspartame in varying drink volumes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of aspartame on pain modulation and its mechanism of action, particularly in combination with calcium channel blockers and nitric oxide synthase inhibitors.
results_summary: Aspartame (0.16% w/v) significantly induced antinociception in both phases of the formalin test, and its effects were potentiated by verapamil and L-NAME, suggesting a role in pain modulation via NMDA receptor activation.
population_specificity: Mice
interactions: Potentiation of antinociception with verapamil (5 mg/kg) and L-NAME (10 mg/kg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame, at an acute dosage of 50 mg/kg, could provoke seizures in individuals who reported seizures allegedly related to aspartame consumption.
results_summary: The study found no clinical seizures or adverse effects after aspartame ingestion, despite increased plasma phenylalanine levels. Results suggest aspartame is no more likely than placebo to cause seizures in this population.
population_specificity: 18 individuals (16 adults and 2 children) who reported seizures allegedly linked to aspartame consumption.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg, administered in divided doses at 0800, 1000, and 1200 h on study days 2 and 4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame affects complex mental operations, particularly aviation-relevant cognitive tasks, compared to placebo and alcohol.
results_summary: The study found no detectable performance decrements associated with aspartame, unlike the ethanol condition, which showed impairments in psychomotor and spatial abilities. Results did not support anecdotal concerns about aspartame's negative cognitive effects.
population_specificity: Thirteen pilots tested under controlled conditions.
study_duration: Five testing sessions (pretest, posttest, and three treatment sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame-sweetened beverages affect subjective hunger, energy intake, and macronutrient selection at a lunch-time meal.
results_summary: The study found no effects of aspartame-sweetened beverages on energy intake, macronutrient selection, or food choice, though restrained eaters consumed more than nonrestrained eaters. Consumption of two soft drinks (560 ml, 320 mg aspartame) temporarily reduced subjective hunger compared to one soft drink or water.
population_specificity: 20 normal-weight young adult males, classified as restrained or nonrestrained eaters.
effective_dosage: 160 mg (280 ml) or 320 mg (560 ml) aspartame, administered once.
study_duration: Single administration, effects measured over 3 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phenylalanine, a breakdown product of aspartame, accounts for aspartame's anorexic effect by suppressing food intake in humans.
results_summary: Capsulated aspartame (400 mg) reduced food intake by 15% in a lunchtime test meal, but neither phenylalanine nor aspartic acid alone had this effect. The study suggests aspartame may intensify satiety effects of ingested food, though the mechanism remains unclear.
population_specificity: Human volunteers
effective_dosage: 400 mg aspartame, 200 mg phenylalanine, 200 mg aspartic acid
study_duration: Single administration with meal test 1 hour later

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of aspartame's constituent amino acids (aspartate and phenylalanine) when administered in capsules versus solution.
results_summary: The study found that aspartame in capsules resulted in a slower absorption rate of phenylalanine compared to solution, with a smaller peak plasma concentration and longer time to peak, but no significant difference in overall absorption extent. The maximum plasma Phe/LNAA ratio was also smaller with capsules, while other large neutral amino acids remained unaffected.
population_specificity: 20 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aspartame on learning, behavior, and mood in children compared to other sweeteners.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of aspartame on associative learning, arithmetic calculation, activity level, social interaction, or mood in experiment 1. In experiment 2, minor and gross motor behaviors were less frequent after sucrose consumption compared to aspartame.
population_specificity: Healthy 9- to 10-year-old children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame increases susceptibility to metrazol-induced convulsions and its effects on plasma and brain levels of phenylalanine and tyrosine in mice and guinea-pigs.
results_summary: Aspartame did not potentiate metrazol-induced convulsions in mice or guinea-pigs, even at high doses (up to 2 g/kg). It significantly increased phenylalanine and tyrosine levels in plasma and brain, but only at higher doses, with no observed changes in monoamine or metabolite levels in brain striata.
population_specificity: CD1 and DBA/2J mice, guinea-pigs, and rats (as positive controls).
effective_dosage: 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 2 g/kg body weight (administered orally to mice and intraperitoneally to guinea-pigs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of aspartame on plasma and brain phenylalanine and tyrosine levels, as well as monoamine concentrations in the corpora striatum of male rats.
results_summary: Aspartame administration led to increased phenylalanine and tyrosine levels in plasma and brain, peaking at 60 minutes. No significant changes in monoamine levels were observed in the corpora striatum up to 5 hours after dosing.
population_specificity: Male rats
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg and 1000 mg/kg body weight (single oral dose)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame affects hunger, fullness, desire to eat, or food intake in children compared to other sweeteners (sodium cyclamate and sucrose).
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of aspartame on subjective feelings of appetite or lunch-time food intake in children, whether consumed alone or with carbohydrates, compared to sodium cyclamate or sucrose.
population_specificity: 20 healthy 9-10-year-old children per experiment.
effective_dosage: Experiment 1: 34 mg/kg aspartame; Experiment 2: 9.7 mg/kg aspartame.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high doses of aspartame administered during late gestation in mice affected developmental parameters, particularly the visual system.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effects on maternal health, reproductive indices, or offspring development, including visual system development, even at extremely high doses of aspartame.
population_specificity: CF-1 mice (offspring of maternal administration during late gestation)
effective_dosage: 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 mg/kg body weight by oral gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gestational exposure to aspartame affects odor-associative learning in newborn guinea pigs.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of aspartame on maternal weight gain, litter size, or birth weight, but it disrupted odor-associative learning in 15-day-old guinea pigs exposed to LiCl.
population_specificity: Pregnant guinea pigs and their offspring.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg administered in sesame oil by gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether large doses of aspartame or L-phenylalanine affect seizure susceptibility and severity in a primate model of epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found no changes in epileptic responses 1-5 hours after administering aspartame or L-phenylalanine, indicating that acute increases in plasma phenylalanine concentration are neither pro- nor anticonvulsant.
population_specificity: Baboons (Papio papio) from Senegal with photosensitive epileptic responses similar to primary generalized epilepsy in humans.
effective_dosage: Aspartame doses of 300 or 1000 mg/kg, administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame affects seizure threshold or strength in rats using an electrical kindling model of epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that aspartame administration (25-2000 mg/kg) affected afterdischarge threshold or seizure strength in rats, even when serum and brain levels of neutral amino acids were elevated. Previous studies on aspartame's potential to induce seizures have yielded mixed results.
population_specificity: Rats (amygdala and hippocampal kindled seizure model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding aspartame-sweetened foods and beverages to a low-fat, hypocaloric diet improves compliance and enhances weight loss.
results_summary: Males achieved clinically significant weight loss in both groups, while females lost more weight in the aspartame-supplemented group (16.5 lb vs. 12.8 lb). Both groups showed improvements in sleep, energy, physical activity, and well-being.
population_specificity: 59 obese men and women (130-225% of ideal body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame consumption was more likely to cause headaches compared to a placebo in individuals who reported headaches after consuming aspartame-containing products.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in headache incidence between aspartame (35%) and placebo (45%). No serious adverse effects or changes in vital signs or plasma concentrations were observed, though subjects with headaches had lower plasma norepinephrine and epinephrine levels.
population_specificity: 40 subjects who reported repeated headaches after aspartame consumption, mostly well-educated, overweight, and with a personal or family history of allergic reactions.
effective_dosage: 30 mg of aspartame per kilogram of body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspartame affects plasma and brain amino acid concentrations in humans and rats under different dietary conditions.
results_summary: Aspartame had no significant effect on plasma amino acid concentrations in humans under realistic consumption conditions. In rats, acute dosing altered plasma amino acids, but subacute treatment showed no significant changes in plasma, brain amino acids, or brain monoamines.
population_specificity: Fasted human volunteers (n=30) and rats.
effective_dosage: 0.83 and 8.3 mg aspartame/kg body weight in humans; included in diet for rats.
study_duration: Acute (single dose) and subacute (14 days) in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether phenylalanine and aspartame affect short-term energy intake, macronutrient selection, and subjective feelings of hunger, mood, and arousal in normal-weight adult males.
results_summary: The study found that neither phenylalanine nor aspartame altered energy intake or macronutrient selection, nor did they affect subjective feelings of hunger, mood, or arousal, despite increased plasma phenylalanine levels. No treatment effects or interactions were observed for any variable.
population_specificity: Normal-weight adult males
study_duration: Short-term (lunch began 60 to 105 minutes after consumption)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aspartame on neurotransmitter concentrations in various brain regions of mice and assess potential neurologic and behavioral disturbances.
results_summary: Aspartame increased norepinephrine concentrations in the hypothalamus, medulla oblongata, and corpus striatum, as well as dopamine and its metabolites in various regions, while serotonin and its metabolite remained unaffected. These changes suggest aspartame may influence brain catecholamine levels, potentially contributing to reported clinical and behavioral effects.
population_specificity: Unfasted male CD-1 mice
effective_dosage: 13, 130, or 650 mg/kg ASM in corn oil (single dose)
study_duration: Single dose, effects measured 3 hours post-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure serum methanol concentrations in rats and humans after oral aspartame administration to assess its metabolic effects.
results_summary: Aspartame administration caused a temporary rise in serum methanol in both rats and humans, with peak levels occurring within 1 hour in rats and 45 minutes in humans, returning to baseline within 4 hours and 2 hours, respectively. The peak methanol levels remained within the range of individual basal levels.
population_specificity: Rats and four male adult volunteers.
effective_dosage: Rats: 34 mg/kg (single dose); Humans: 500 mg (6-8.7 mg/kg, single dose).
study_duration: Single administration with follow-up measurements up to 4 hours in rats and 2 hours in humans.

study_goal: The researchers were comparing the effects of carbohydrate ingestion versus a placebo (saccharin and aspartame solution) on force output and time to exhaustion during static muscle contractions.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of the aspartame-containing placebo on force output or time to exhaustion compared to carbohydrate ingestion, which significantly improved both metrics. The placebo group showed lower performance outcomes.
population_specificity: Six trained male subjects
effective_dosage: Equal volume of a solution made of saccharin and aspartame (exact dosage not specified)
study_duration: Until failure occurred during the exercise protocol (PL group mean = 16.0 ± 8.1 minutes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize immune cell interactions and dysregulation in anti-NMDARE using single-cell multi-omics sequencing technologies.
results_summary: The study revealed significant B cell clonal expansion, particularly in plasma cells, driven by antigen recognition, and identified IFN-I and TLR2 pathway activation as potential contributors to immune dysregulation.
population_specificity: Patients in the acute phase of anti-NMDARE and healthy controls.

study_goal: To assess whether D-serine supplementation can mitigate synaptic plasticity impairments caused by anti-NMDAR antibodies in a mouse model of anti-NMDAR encephalitis.
results_summary: D-serine improved hippocampal long-term potentiation impairments caused by anti-NMDAR antibodies but did not reverse decreased NMDAR expression. No significant behavioral differences were observed between treated and control mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice injected with anti-NMDAR antibodies from human patients.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg intraperitoneally for three consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) in childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus (cSLE), including the role of elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels.
results_summary: Elevated AST levels (≥61 U/L) were identified as a predictor of MAS occurrence in cSLE patients, alongside other markers like ferritin and LDH. The study found no recurrence of MAS in patients during an 18-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 157 patients diagnosed with childhood-onset systemic lupus erythematosus (cSLE), with or without MAS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, highlighting its presentation, diagnosis, and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that a 24-year-old female with anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis showed significant improvement after treatment with high-dose corticosteroids and intravenous immunoglobulin, with follow-up MRI confirming reduced lesion size. The case underscores the importance of early diagnosis and awareness of atypical presentations.
population_specificity: 24-year-old female with no significant medical history.
effective_dosage: High-dose corticosteroids and intravenous immunoglobulin (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of insulin and magnesium supplements on the expression of GABAergic and NMDA receptors, including N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA), in the stomach of type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium and insulin improved NOS-1 expression and restored GABA-A and GABA-B receptor levels in diabetic rats, with magnesium showing a stronger effect. Insulin also improved GABA-A receptor expression, but NMDA receptor levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with type 2 diabetes induced by a high-fat diet and low-dose streptozotocin.
study_duration: Three months (high-fat diet) + treatment duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how serum levels of D- and L-aspartate vary across different stages of psychosis progression and their potential as biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found that increased D-aspartate/total aspartate ratios were associated with early stages of psychosis, while elevated L-aspartate levels were linked to chronic schizophrenia. These changes suggest dysregulation in aspartate metabolism during psychosis progression.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with At-Risk Mental State (ARMS), First Episode of Psychosis (FEP), full-blown schizophrenia, and Healthy Donors (HD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential and risks of memantine as an adjunct therapy for N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor encephalitis (NMDARE), focusing on its dual effects on symptom reduction and neuronal communication impairment.
results_summary: Memantine showed variable effectiveness in treating NMDARE, with potential benefits from blocking excessive NMDA receptor antibody binding but risks from reducing extracellular NMDAR availability, impairing neuronal communication. Comprehensive analyses remain scarce, highlighting the need for further investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor encephalitis (NMDARE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of anti-NMDAR encephalitis and its management, highlighting diagnostic challenges and treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study reported a 19-year-old female with anti-NMDAR encephalitis presenting with catatonia and other neurological symptoms, diagnosed using clinical criteria and antibody testing. Treatment with methylprednisolone and plasma exchanges was initiated, emphasizing the need for refined therapeutic approaches.
population_specificity: 19-year-old female with anti-NMDAR encephalitis and an ovarian teratoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the treatment outcomes of anti-NMDAR encephalitis associated with small cell lung cancer, focusing on the effectiveness of immunotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that immunotherapy alone was insufficient for treating anti-NMDAR encephalitis caused by small cell lung cancer, as the patient showed no improvement in consciousness and ultimately died. Combined immunotherapy and cancer therapy is suggested for better outcomes.
population_specificity: A 66-year-old man with anti-NMDAR encephalitis and small cell lung cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe an unusual presentation of paraneoplastic neurological syndrome (PNS) with dual antibody positivity in a patient diagnosed with lung cancer.
results_summary: The study reported an unusual case of PNS with dual antibody positivity in a lung cancer patient, highlighting the variability in PNS presentations and the importance of updated diagnostic criteria.
population_specificity: A single patient diagnosed with lung cancer presenting with PNS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate antibodies and paraneoplastic encephalitis in a patient with an ovarian teratoma.
results_summary: The study found that the presence of anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid was linked to paraneoplastic encephalitis, and surgical removal of the ovarian teratoma led to resolution of symptoms.
population_specificity: 22-year-old female with refractory insomnia, disorganized behavior, and visual hallucinations.
study_duration: Treatment initiated upon admission; surgery performed on day 25.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating whether human norovirus (NoV) infection could be a trigger for anti-NMDAR encephalitis.
results_summary: The study reported a case of a 15-month-old girl with NoV infection who developed anti-NMDAR encephalitis, suggesting a possible link between NoV infection and this neurological condition. Treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin and glucocorticoid led to almost complete recovery.
population_specificity: 15-month-old girl with NoV infection and neurological symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fluoroquinolone-based antibiotics (norfloxacin, ciprofloxacin, and sparfloxacin) could inhibit plasmepsin II (an aspartate protease) and serve as potential antimalarial drugs.
